00033 //*
00034 // The entry point of the application.
00035 // \param argc The number of command line arguments in argv.
00036 // \param argv The array of command line arguments.
00037 // \return Zero if execution was successful. -1 if an unrecoverable error occurred during execution.
00038 int main(int argc, char* argv[])
00039 {
00040         // Search in the current working directory if no argument was provided
00041         char* searchPath = (argc > 1)
00042                 ? argv[1]
00043                 : ".";
00044 
00045         // Start the search at the specified path
00046         do_file(searchPath, argv);
00047 
00048         return 0;
00049 }
00050 
00051 
00052 
00053 //*
00054 // Recursively walks through all the files and directories below the specified path and prints the information of each entry according to the actions specified in parms.
00055 // \param file_name The path of the file or directory to process.
00056 // \param parms The array of command line arguments representing the actions used for printing the information of each file or directory entry.
00057 void do_file(const char* file_name, const char* const parms[])
00058 {
00059         struct stat fileInfo;
00060 
00061         // Read file information (without following symbolic links)
00062         int result = lstat(file_name, &fileInfo);
00063 
00064         if (result == -1)
00065         {
00066                 fprintf(stderr, "Reading information of file \"%s\" has failed with error code %d: %s\n", file_name, errno, strerror(errno));
00067 
00068                 return;
00069         }
00070 
00071         // Print the information of this file or directory
00072         PrintFileInformation(file_name, &fileInfo, parms);
00073 
00074         // Continue the search in subdirectories if the "file" is actually a directory
00075         if (S_ISDIR(fileInfo.st_mode))
00076         {
00077                 do_dir(file_name, parms);
00078         }
00079 }
00080 
00081 //*
00082 // Enumerates the files and directories below the specified directory path and prints the information of each entry according to the actions specified in parms.
00083 // \param dir_name The path of the directory to process.
00084 // \param parms The array of command line arguments representing the actions used for printing the information of each file or directory entry.
00085 void do_dir(const char* dir_name, const char* const parms[])
00086 {
00087         // TODO: Change the working directory to the provided one. Otherwise, reading file information will fail if the paths get too long.
00088 
00089 
00090         // Open the specified directory
00091         DIR* pDir = opendir(dir_name);
00092 
00093         if (pDir == NULL)
00094         {
00095                 fprintf(stderr, "Opening directory \"%s\" has failed with error code %d: %s\n", dir_name, errno, strerror(errno));
00096 
00097                 return;
00098         }
00099 
00100 
00101         struct dirent* directoryInfo = NULL;
00102 
00103         do
00104         {
00105                 // Reset error for the subsequent library call
00106                 errno = 0;
00107 
00108                 // Read directory information
00109                 directoryInfo = readdir(pDir);
00110 
00111                 if (directoryInfo == NULL)
00112                 {
00113                         // If no error value is set, it indicates that the end of the directory stream has been reached
00114                         if (errno != 0)
00115                                 fprintf(stderr, "Reading directory \"%s\" has failed with error code %d: %s\n", dir_name, errno, strerror(errno));
00116 
00117                         break;
00118                 }
00119 
00120 
00121                 // Ignore the directory entries that represent the current and the parent directory
00122                 if (!strcmp(directoryInfo->d_name, ".") || !strcmp(directoryInfo->d_name, ".."))
00123                         continue;
00124 
00125 
00126                 // TODO:
00127                 // CombinePath() might be unnecessary since the file system accepts duplicated
00128                 // slashes in paths (".////doc" will be treated the same as "./doc"). Simply
00129                 // concatenate dir_name and directoryInfo->d_name with a slash in between.
00130 
00131                 // Construct the combined path of the file, taking care of 
00132                 char* filePath = CombinePath(dir_name, directoryInfo->d_name);
00133 
00134                 // Process files and directories below the current one
00135                 do_file(filePath, parms);
00136 
00137                 // Free the previously allocated, combined path string
00138                 free(filePath);
00139         } while (directoryInfo != NULL);
00140 
00141 
00142         // Close the directory
00143         int result = closedir(pDir);
00144 
00145         if (result == -1)
00146         {
00147                 fprintf(stderr, "Closing directory \"%s\" has failed with error code %d: %s\n", dir_name, errno, strerror(errno));
00148 
00149                 return;
00150         }
00151 }
00152 
00153 
00154 //*
00155 // Concatenates the provided path strings into a single path, adding or removing the intermediate directory separator as necessary.
00156 // \param path1 The first path to combine.
00157 // \param path2 The second path to combine.
00158 // \return The combined path as a newly allocated string, which needs to be released with free().
00159 char* CombinePath(const char* path1, const char* path2)
00160 {
00161         // Determine the number of characters in the input strings
00162         int path1Len = strlen(path1);
00163         int path2Len = strlen(path2);
00164 
00165         // Check if both or either of the strings is empty
00166         if ((path1Len == 0) && (path2Len == 0))
00167         {
00168                 return strdup("");
00169         }
00170         else if (path1Len == 0)
00171         {
00172                 return strdup(path2);
00173         }
00174         else if (path2Len == 0)
00175         {
00176                 return strdup(path1);
00177         }
00178 
00179 
00180         // Allocate sufficient memory for concatenating the paths plus the directory separator and string terminator
00181         char* combined = calloc(path1Len + path2Len + 2, sizeof(char));
00182 
00183         if (combined == NULL)
00184         {
00185                 // Out of memory
00186                 exit(-1);
00187         }
00188 
00189 
00190         // Check if the first path ends with a directory-separating slash
00191         int path1HasTrailingSlash =
00192                 (path1Len > 0) && (path1[path1Len - 1] == '/');
00193 
00194         // Check if the second path starts with a directory-separating slash
00195         int path2HasLeadingSlash =
00196                 (path2Len > 0) && (path2[0] == '/');
00197 
00198         if (path1HasTrailingSlash && path2HasLeadingSlash)
00199         {
00200                 // Both paths contain a slash; Trim the slash from the first path and concatenate
00201                 strncat(combined, path1, path1Len - 1);
00202                 strcat(combined, path2);
00203         }
00204         else if (path1HasTrailingSlash || path2HasLeadingSlash)
00205         {
00206                 // Only one path contains a slash; Concatenate the paths as they are
00207                 strcat(combined, path1);
00208                 strcat(combined, path2);
00209         }
00210         else
00211         {
00212                 // Neither path contains a slash; Concatenate the paths with a slash in between
00213                 strcat(combined, path1);
00214                 strcat(combined, "/");
00215                 strcat(combined, path2);
00216         }
00217 
00218         return combined;
00219 }

00221 void PrintFileInformation(const char* filePath, const struct stat* fileInformation, const char* const parms[])
00222 {
00223         // TODO:
00224         // Apply the command line actions to determine whether this file should
00225         // be ignored. Exit without printing any information in that case.
00226 
00227         // TODO:
00228         // Print in extended format when the -ls action was specified.
00229 
00230         // Print the file information
00231         printf("%s\n", filePath);
00232 }
